definitions.definition: to move forward on your hands and knees or with your body close to the ground

examples.text: Our baby is just starting to crawl.
A man was crawling away from the burning wreckage.
As night fell, we managed to crawl back to our lines.
Has the baby started to crawl yet?
We spent an hour crawling around on our hands and knees looking for the key.
She was forced to crawl along through the thickening mist.

definitions.definition: when an insect, a spider, etc. crawls, it moves forward on its legs

examples.text: There's a spider crawling up your leg.
The traffic was crawling as I left the city.
The taxi crawled to a halt.

definitions.definition: to be too friendly or helpful to somebody in authority, in a way that is not sincere, especially in order to get an advantage from them

examples.text: She's always crawling to the boss.

definitions.definition: to search the internet in order to record and list data

examples.text: A protocol controls which pages a web crawler will crawl.

definitions.definition: if you say that somebody comes/crawls out of the woodwork, you mean that they have suddenly appeared in order to express an opinion or to take advantage of a situation

examples.text: When he won the lottery, all sorts of distant relatives came out of the woodwork.

definitions.definition: to make you feel afraid or full of horror

examples.text: Just the sight of him makes my skin crawl.

wordOrigin: Middle English: of unknown origin; possibly related to Swedish kravla and Danish kravle.
